facts.text: This is an appeal from a judgment and decree of the Patna High Court dated 25th March 1949 in A.S. 2280 of 1948

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from a judgment and decree of the Patna High Court dated 25th March, 1949, in A.S. 2280 of 1948 reversing an appellate decree of the Subordinate Judge in Suit No. 62 of 1948.

facts.text: Patna High Court reversed appellate decree of the Subordinate Judge in Suit No. 62 of 1948

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from a judgment and decree of the Patna High Court dated 25th March, 1949, in A.S. 2280 of 1948 reversing an appellate decree of the Subordinate Judge in Suit No. 62 of 1948.

facts.text: Respondents have been in occupation as a monthly tenant of several blocks of premises belonging to the appellants at a monthly rental of Rs. 112

anchor.surface_text: The respondents have been in occupation as a monthly tenant of several blocks of premises belonging to the appellants at a monthly rental of Rs. 112.

facts.text: Rent for the months of March, April and May 1942 fell into arrears

anchor.surface_text: The rent for the months of March, April and May, 1942, having fallen into arrears, they remitted it along with the rent for June,

facts.text: Respondents remitted arrears along with rent for June on 28th June 1947 by means of two cheques

anchor.surface_text: The rent for the months of March, April and May, 1942, having fallen into arrears, they remitted it along with the rent for June, on 28th June, 1947, by means of two cheques.

facts.text: Appellants did not accept the cheques

anchor.surface_text: As the appellants did not accept the cheques, on 4th August, 1947, the respondents remitted the amount subsequently by postal money order.

facts.text: On 4th August 1947 respondents remitted the amount by postal money order

anchor.surface_text: As the appellants did not accept the cheques, on 4th August, 1947, the respondents remitted the amount subsequently by postal money order.

facts.text: On 12th August 1947 appellants applied to the House Controller for eviction of respondents under section 11(1)(a) of Bihar Act III of 1947 maintaining non-payment of rent

anchor.surface_text: On 12th August, 1947, the appellants, maintaining that there was non-payment of rent -and hence the respondents were liable to be evicted, under section 11 1 a of the Bihar Buildings Lease, Rent and Eviction Control Act, 1947 Bihar Act III of 1947 , applied to the House Controller for the eviction of the respondents from the premises.

facts.text: On 30th August 1947 respondents deposited rent up to June in the Office of the House Controller after money order returned

anchor.surface_text: On 30th August, 1947, the respondents, whose money order had in the meantime been returned by the appellants, deposited the rent up to the month of June in the Office of the House Controller.

facts.text: House Controller passed order on 10th November 1947 directing eviction by 10th May 1948 holding non-payment of rent

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding this deposit, the House Controller passed an order on the both November, directing the eviction of the respondents by 10th May, 1948, and holding that they had made themselves liable to eviction by reason of non-payment of rent.

facts.text: Order of House Controller upheld by Commissioner on appeal on 27th April 1948

anchor.surface_text: The order of the House Controller was upheld by the Commissioner on appeal on the 27th April, 1948,

facts.text: Respondents filed suit in Patna Munsifs Court for declaration that order of Controller dated 10th November 1947 was illegal ultra vires and without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: and thereupon the respondents filed the present suit in the Patna Munsifs Court for a declaration that the order of the ContrOller dated the 10th November, 1947, was illegal, ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Suit No. 62 of 1948

anchor.surface_text: in Suit No. 62 of 1948.

facts.text: Suit dismissed by Munsif

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the Munsif and his decree was upheld on appeal,

facts.text: Munsif decree upheld on appeal by Subordinate Judge

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the Munsif and his decree was upheld on appeal, but the High Court decreed the suit

facts.text: High Court decreed the suit holding order of Rent Controller without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: but the High Court decreed the suit holding that the order of the Rent Controller was without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Appellants granted leave to appeal by High Court

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were thereafter granted leave to appeal by the High Court, and they have accordingly preferred this appeal.

facts.text: At inception of tenancy respondents paid one months rent in advance

anchor.surface_text: It appears that at the inception of the tenancy, the respondents had paid one months rent in advance,

facts.text: Agreed between respondents and appellants that advance rent would be adjusted whenever default in payment of rent for full one month

anchor.surface_text: and it had been agreed between them and the appellants that the advance rent would be adjusted whenever there was default in payment of rent for full one month.

facts.text: Advance payment could be adjusted only for one months rent but here rent for three months due

anchor.surface_text: It was however pointed out that the advance payment could be adjusted only for one months rent, but, in the present case, the rent for three months had become due,

facts.text: Rent for March became due in April

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that the rent for the month of March became due in April and the rent for April became due in May,

facts.text: No step taken by respondents to pay arrears until 28th June 1947

anchor.surface_text: but no step was taken by the respondents to pay the arrears until the 28th June, 1947.

facts.text: Respondents contention that there was no non-payment of rent

anchor.surface_text: The main ground on which the respondents have attacked the order of eviction passed by the House Controller is that in fact there was no non-payment of rent,

facts.text: Appellants contention that there was non-payment of rent since not paid as and when due

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, one of the contentions put forward on behalf of the appellants is that there was non-payment of rent within the meaning of that expression as used in the Act, since the rent was not paid as and when it fell due.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on February 2 1951 by FAZL ALL J

anchor.surface_text: 1951. February 2. The judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZL ALL J.--This is an appeal from a judgment and decree of the High Court
under section 11 1 a of the Bihar Buildings Lease, Rent and Eviction Control Act, 1947 Bihar Act III of 1947 , applied to the House Controller for the eviction of the respondents from the premises.

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 1 a of the Act runs as follows -- Notwithstanding anything companytained in any agreement or law to the companytrary and subject to the provisions of section 12, where a tenant is in possession of any building, he shall number be liable to be evicted therefrom, whether in execution of a decree or otherwise, except-- a in the case of a month to month tenant, for number- payment of rent or breach of the companyditions of the tenancy, or for subletting the building or any portion thereof with- out the companysent of the landlord, or if he is an employee of the landlord occupying the building as an employee, on his ceasing to be in such employment

anchor.surface_text: The law on this subject has been very lucidly stated by Lord Esher M.R. in The Queen v. Commissioners for Special Purposes of the Income Tax , in these words -- When an inferior companyrt or tribunal or body, which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first estab- lished by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to companysider what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things, but number otherwise. There it is number for them companyclu- sively to decide whether that state of facts exists, and, if they exercise the jurisdiction without its existence, what they do may be questioned, and it will be held that they have acted without jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether the decision of the House Controller on whether there was non-payment of rent (the condition precedent for eviction under section 11(1)(a)) can be questioned or collaterally impeached in a civil court, given the finality provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Act empowers the Controller alone to decide whether or not there is non-payment of rent, and his decision on that question is essential before an order can be passed by him under section 11. Such being the provisions of the Act we have to see whether it is at all possible to question the decision of the Controller on a matter which the Act clearly empowers him to decide.

issues.text: Whether there was non-payment of rent within the meaning of section 11(1)(a) of the Bihar Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Act, 1947, given the tenants' attempts to remit rent by cheque and money order (not accepted) and subsequent deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The main ground on which the respondents have attacked the order of eviction passed by the House Controller is that in fact there was no non-payment of rent, and, since no eviction can be ordered under the Bihar Act unless non-payment is established, the House Controller had no jurisdiction to order eviction.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'non-payment of rent' in section 11(1)(a) must be interpreted by reference to ordinary law principles under the Transfer of Property Act (including relief against forfeiture) and the Act's preamble, such that deposit of arrears before the eviction order precludes eviction.

anchor.surface_text: after referring to section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act, proceeded to propound its own view in these words-- Regard being had to the circumstances in which the Act under consideration was enacted and its object, as stated in the preamble as being to prevent unreasonable eviction of tenants from buildings, it would seem that the expression non-payment of rent in section 11 in the context in which it is used must be given an interpretation which would have the effect of enlarging the protection against determination of a tenancy enjoyed by a tenant under the ordinary law.

arguments.claim: There was no non-payment of rent, and since no eviction can be ordered under the Bihar Act unless non-payment is established, the House Controller had no jurisdiction to order eviction.

anchor.surface_text: The main ground on which the respondents have attacked the order of eviction passed by the House Controller is that in fact there was no non-payment of rent, and, since no eviction can be ordered under the Bihar Act unless non-payment is established, the House Controller had no jurisdiction to order eviction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Act self-contained; Controller empowered to decide non-payment as jurisdictional fact; final per s.18(3); precedents support no collateral challenge.

arguments.claim: There was non-payment of rent within the meaning of that expression as used in the Act, since the rent was not paid as and when it fell due.

arguments.claim: The Buildings Control Act has authorised the Controller to decide whether or not there is non-payment of rent and it is only when he is satisfied that there has been non-payment of rent that he assumes jurisdiction. Civil Court cannot collaterally impeach such decision.

anchor.surface_text: But the Buildings Control Act has authorised the Controller to decide whether or not there is non-payment of rent and it is only when he is satisfied that there has been non-payment of rent that he assumes jurisdiction. If the question of jurisdiction depends upon the decision of some fact or point of law, and if the court is called upon to decide such question, then such decision cannot be collaterally impeached.

arguments.claim: Controller's decision on whether irregular payment amounts to non-payment (question of law) is not final under s.18(3); otherwise curtails tenant protection and enlarges landlord rights beyond ordinary law.

anchor.surface_text: If, as contended for on behalf of the respondents, section 11 of the Act were to be construed as entitling a landlord to apply for eviction of a tenant on the ground of irregular payment of rent amounting to non-payment of rent and as empowering the Controller to determine as to whether irregular payment of rent amounts to non-payment of rent within the meaning of sub-section (1) of section 11, and subsection (3) of section 18 were to be construed as making the decision of the Controller on this question of law a final one, it will appear that not only this Act will have conferred a right upon the landlord very much in excess of the right that he enjoys under the ordinary law...

arguments.court_reasoning: Overruled by High Court; but accepted by Supreme Court.

arguments.claim: Section 11 is self-contained; notwithstanding ordinary law; tenant liable to eviction for non-payment without importing TP Act; Controller decides under powers in ss.11(8)(b),16,18(3).

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is not correct. Section 11 begins with the words Notwithstanding anything contained in any agreement or law to the contrary, and hence any attempt to import the provisions relating to the law of transfer of property for the interpretation of the section would seem to be out of place. Section 11 is a self-contained section, and it is wholly unnecessary to go outside the Act for determining whether a tenant is liable to be evicted or not, and under what conditions he can be evicted.

arguments.claim: The Act sets up complete machinery for investigation of jurisdictional facts like non-payment; Controller's order final subject to Commissioner per s.18(3); cannot be questioned in civil court.
Legislature may entrust tribunal with jurisdiction to determine preliminary jurisdictional facts; such decision not collaterally challengeable even if erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: The law on this subject has been very lucidly stated by Lord Esher M.R. in The Queen v. Commissioners for Special Purposes of the Income Tax, in these words -- When an inferior court or tribunal or body, which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to consider what powers it will give that tribunal or body...

arguments.claim: Adjudication by tribunal with subject-matter jurisdiction conclusive on facts; no certiorari to quash for erroneous finding of essential jurisdictional fact.

anchor.surface_text: On the same lines are the following observations of Sir James Colville in The Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan, which is a case dealing with the principles on which a writ of certiorari may be issued -- Accordingly, the authorities establish that an adjudication by a Judge having jurisdiction over the subject-matter is, if no defect appears on the face of it, to be taken as conclusive of the facts stated therein...

holdings.text: It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is not correct. Section 11 is a self-contained section, and it is wholly unnecessary to go outside the Act for determining whether a tenant is liable to be evicted or not, and under what conditions he can be evicted.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is not correct. Section 11 begins with the words Notwithstanding anything contained in any agreement or law to the contrary, and hence any attempt to import the provisions relating to the law of transfer of property for the interpretation of the section would seem to be out of place. Section 11 is a self-contained section, and it is wholly unnecessary to go outside the Act for determining whether a tenant is liable to be evicted or not, and under what conditions he can be evicted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 11 opens with 'Notwithstanding anything contained in any agreement or law to the contrary'; rejects importation of Transfer of Property Act section 111 and equity relief against forfeiture; Act provides conditions for eviction internally.

holdings.text: The Act empowers the Controller alone to decide whether or not there is non-payment of rent, and his decision on that question is essential before an order can be passed by him under section 11.

anchor.surface_text: The Act empowers the Controller alone to decide whether or not there is non-payment of rent, and his decision on that question is essential before an order can be passed by him under section 11. Such being the provisions of the Act we have to see whether it is at all possible to question the decision of the Controller on a matter which the Act clearly empowers him to decide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Controller has enquiry powers (section 16 like CPC), satisfaction required (section 11(8)(b)), finality subject only to Commissioner (section 18(3)); complete statutory machinery precludes civil court interference.

holdings.text: The legislature may entrust the tribunal or body with a jurisdiction, which includes the jurisdiction to determine whether the preliminary state of facts exists as well as the jurisdiction, on finding that it does exist, to proceed further or do something more... there is no appeal from such exercise of their jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The law on this subject has been very lucidly stated by Lord Esher M.R. in The Queen v. Commissioners for Special Purposes of the Income Tax , in these words -- When an inferior court or tribunal or body, which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to consider what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things, but not otherwise. There it is not for them conclusively to decide whether that state of facts exists, and, if they exercise the jurisdiction without its existence, what they do may be questioned, and it will be held that they have acted without jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applies doctrine from Queen v. Commissioners for Special Purposes of Income Tax (Lord Esher MR): where statute gives tribunal power over preliminary jurisdictional facts (non-payment), decision binding even if erroneous; no collateral challenge.

holdings.text: An adjudication by a Judge having jurisdiction over the subject-matter is, if no defect appears on the face of it, to be taken as conclusive of the facts stated therein and that the Court of Queens Bench will not on certiorari quash such an adjudication on the ground that any such fact, however essential, has been erroneously found.

anchor.surface_text: On the same lines are the following observations of Sir James Colville in The Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan , which is a case dealing with the principles on which a writ of certiorari may be issued -- Accordingly, the authorities establish that an adjudication by a Judge having jurisdiction over the subject-matter is, if no defect appears on the face of it, to be taken as conclusive of the facts stated therein and that the Court of Queens Bench will not on certiorari quash such an adjudication on the ground that any such fact, however essential, has been erroneously found.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan (Sir James Colville): tribunal adjudication conclusive on jurisdictional facts if no facial defect; supports no collateral impeachment in civil suit analogous to no certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is not correct. Section 11 begins with the words Notwithstanding anything contained in any agreement or law to the contrary, and hence any attempt to import the provisions relating to the law of transfer of property for the interpretation of the section would seem to be out of place. Section 11 is a self-contained section, and it is wholly unnecessary to go outside the Act for determining whether a tenant is liable to be evicted or not, and under what conditions he can be evicted.
It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is number companyrect.
n the Code of Civil Procedure. Section 18 pro- vides that any person aggrieved by an order passed by the Controller may within 15 days of the receipt

edges.explanation: Holding h2 directly states the Controller's exclusive power to decide non-payment, addressing the issue i1 of whether that decision can be questioned collaterally

anchor.surface_text: The Act empowers the Controller alone to decide whether or not there is non-payment of rent, and his decision on that question is essential before an order can be passed by him under section 11. Such being the provisions of the Act we have to see whether it is at all possible to question the decision of the Controller on a matter which the Act clearly empowers him to decide.
It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is number companyrect.

anchor.surface_text: The law on this subject has been very lucidly stated by Lord Esher M.R. in The Queen v. Commissioners for Special Purposes of the Income Tax , in these words -- When an inferior court or tribunal or body, which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to consider what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things, but not otherwise. There it is not for them conclusively to decide whether that state of facts exists, and, if they exercise the jurisdiction without its existence, what they do may be questioned, and it will be held that they have acted without jurisdiction.
It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is number companyrect.
e is another state of things which may exist. The legislature may intrust the tribunal or body with a jurisdiction, which includes the jurisdiction to

anchor.surface_text: On the same lines are the following observations of Sir James Colville in The Colonial Bank of Australasia v. Willan , which is a case dealing with the principles on which a writ of certiorari may be issued -- Accordingly, the authorities establish that an adjudication by a Judge having jurisdiction over the subject-matter is, if no defect appears on the face of it, to be taken as conclusive of the facts stated therein and that the Court of Queens Bench will not on certiorari quash such an adjudication on the ground that any such fact, however essential, has been erroneously found.
It seems to us that the view taken by the High Court is number companyrect.
